The dimension of the induced representation can be read
directly off the equation for its construction [equation (3)]:
This result points out the difﬁculties for the direct calculation
of a representation of a space group
. As the site-symmetry group is a
subgroup of an inﬁnite index, this suggests that the dimension
of the induced irreps must be of inﬁnite dimensions. By means
of the site-symmetry approach it is possible to determine the
sentation without the necessity of constructing the inﬁnite-
dimensional representation. The method is based on the
Frobenius reciprocity theorem, according to which the multi-
words, it is sufﬁcient to calculate the multiplicities
2.2. Application of site-symmetry method to layer groups
The group–subgroup relations between layer and space
are essential to extend the site-symmetry
method to layer groups. These relationships have been
considered in detail in the literature [see
and references therein]. The type of space group of which
a given layer group is a subgroup is not deﬁned uniquely. The
results in close relationships between the Wyckoff positions
. One can show that the set of
Wyckoff positions of a layer group is contained in the set of
Wyckoff positions of the related space group (
Smirnov, 1993). For example, consideration of the restrictions
imposed by the loss of periodicity in the third (
yields the following restrictions on the special-position coor-
dinates of layer groups: only the special positions of
coordinate does not involve a fraction of the unit-cell para-
meter are possible special positions of
or 0. In that way, to each Wyckoff
corresponds exactly one Wyckoff position of
speciﬁed by exactly the same site-symmetry group and
multiplicity, and by the same set of coordinate triplets of
equivalent positions. Thus, the description of the Wyckoff
positions of layer groups can follow the Wyckoff-position
descriptions used in space groups. Note, however, that
according to the conventions adopted in
labelling of the Wyckoff positions of layer groups is done
independently of that of space groups. As a result, the
Wyckoff letters of the corresponding space- and layer-group
Wyckoff positions might not coincide, in general.

. The Brillouin zone of a layer
can be described as a projection of the Brillouin zone
